entry.content:

entry.title: Lektion 1: BegrÃ¼ÃŸungen
entry.content:
Itâ€™s a bundle of Germany learning notes. The date is not accurate because itâ€™s usage is to make the correct order of them.

Lesson 1: Greesings, letâ€™s begin!

Lektion 1

BegrÃ¼ÃŸungen (greetings)

  • Hallo â€“Hello

  • Guten Tag â€“Good day

    Can be used in any time of the day, formal

    • Guten Morgen â€“Good morning
    • Guten Abend â€“Good evening
    • Gute Nacht â€“Good Night

  • TschÃ¼ss â€“Bye

    TschÃ¼s, tschÃ¼s, TschÃ¼ss and tschÃ¼ss are all correct, and the preferred spelling depends on the person/the region you are in.

    https://www.duden.de/rechtschreibung/tschues

    • Ciao â€“Bye

  • Auf Wiedersehen! â€“See you again

    • Auf WiederhÃ¶ren! â€“Bye (on telephone)

  • Bis bald â€“See you soon

    • Bis spÃ¤ter â€“See you later
    • Bis dann â€“See you whenever we meet again/ See you then

Bavaria and Austria

Bavaria is the biggest state in Germany

  • GrÃ¼ÃŸ Gott â€“Hello

  • GrÃ¼ÃŸ Sie/ GrÃ¼ÃŸ dich â€“Hello

    Casual greeting, Sie for formal situation, dich for informal situation

    Only in singular form, not suitable for group of people

Switzerland and Southern Germany

  • Servus â€“Hello/Bye

entry.title: expChipsâ€™ Tour of Swift // 1
entry.content:
These days, I accepted some easy problems on leetcode, in order to get familiar to a new programming languageâ€”â€”Swift. In this series, I will write down basic syntax and come useful skills. Mostly, itâ€™s my personal online note.

print()

  // hello_world.swift
  print("hello, world!")

The code above will print "hello, world!\n", and itâ€™s a complete program. I can run it in command line by tapping swift hello_world.swift. Itâ€™s obviously that this language has some feature of script language.

We can add a parameter to change the last character of the string, and by doing this, the print will not wrap:

  // hello_world_unwrap.swift
  print("hello, world!", terminator: "")

And another parameter separator: is also important. You can use it like terminator:

Comments

Swiftâ€™s comments are C++ like. For example:

// luv ğŸŸ
/* luv ğŸ“¦*/

Itâ€™s no need to explain more.

values, variables, and constants

Swift uses different keywords.

  import Darwin // use acos()

  let Pi = acos(0.0) * 2, r: Double = 1
  var s = Pi * r * r

btw. You can interctive with swift like ruby, just tap swift and enter.

You can provide a type annotation when you declare a constant or variable, to be clear about the kind of values the constant or variable can store.

If you provide an initial value for a constant or variable at the point that itâ€™s defined, Swift can almost always infer the type to be used for that constant or variable.

Int

  print(Int.max)    // 9223372036854775807
  print(Int32.max)  // 2147483647
  print(UInt.max)   // 18446744073709551615

Digitals can be separated by _:

  print(2_333_444_555) // 2333444555
entry.summary: These days, I accepted some easy problems on leetcode, in order to get familiar to a new programming languageâ€”â€”Swift. In this series, I will write down basic syntax and come useful skills. Mostly, itâ€™s my personal online note.

entry.title: New Equipment, New Start
entry.content:
Recently, I sold my ASUS Gaming laptop and bought a MacBook Air2020â€”â€” An exciting new device.

I love this kind of machine: productive, elegant, long battery life and most importantlyâ€”â€” portable.

This days I tried developing C++, Ruby and Swift on it, and itâ€™s the best experience I have ever had.

After that, I calmed down, and planned to do something new on itâ€”â€” a grand planâ€”â€” so big that I cannot describe it.

The Meaning of This Site

This siteâ€”â€” Klein log, itâ€™s a place more to share my feelings than experiences. It will be Emotional, not Rational.

In order to do that, I added a new function:

Itâ€™s a intuitive way to track my scoresâ€”â€” mostly Calculus.
entry.summary: Recently, I sold my ASUS Gaming laptop and bought a MacBook Air2020â€”â€” An exciting new device.

entry.title: Defer in Go
entry.content:
å¾ˆå¤šç°ä»£çš„ç¼–ç¨‹è¯­è¨€ä¸­éƒ½æœ‰ defer å…³é”®å­—ï¼ŒGo è¯­è¨€çš„ defer ä¼šåœ¨å½“å‰å‡½æ•°æˆ–è€…æ–¹æ³•è¿”å›ä¹‹å‰æ‰§è¡Œä¼ å…¥çš„å‡½æ•°ã€‚å®ƒä¼šç»å¸¸è¢«ç”¨äºå…³é—­æ–‡ä»¶æè¿°ç¬¦ã€å…³é—­æ•°æ®åº“è¿æ¥ä»¥åŠè§£é”èµ„æºã€‚

When it comes to keyword defer in go, I felt confused.

The teacher showed a piece of code:

func main() {
  i := 1
  defer fmt.Println(i + 1)

  i++
  fmt.Println("hello, world!")
}

I thought that it must print "hello, world!" and 3 at first. But after typing and runing, I was totally shocked â€”â€” Itâ€™s output is "hello, world" and 2!

What actually gets printed as a two, because that i +1 is evaluated right there when the first statement, when it hits the differed statement, the i +1 is evaluated and at that time, i is a one, so i +1 is a two. So, later when the differed statement actually gets executed itâ€™s still prints a two.

entry.title: A better way to implement getMax() in Golang

link.title: A better way to implement getMax() in Golang

entry.content:
In previous assignment, I was asked to implement a function which can pick the biggest number in a slice.

By learning on Coursera, I found a better way to do this.

Ordinary Method

When I started learning Programming in C++, the text book told me that the best way to pick the biggest number in an array is like this:

int getMax(int *a, int len) {
  int flag = a[0];
  for (int i = 1; i < len; ++i)
    if (a[i] > flag)
      flag = a[i];
  return flag
}

Itâ€™s simple, understandable and efficient. I cannot find a better algorithm to work as well as this (in C++).

The â€œBetterâ€ Way in Golang

At the beginning, I wrote a same function as usual in Go like this:

func getMax(arr []int, n int) int {
  var flag int = arr[0]
  for i := 1; i < n; i++ {
    if arr[i] > flag {
      flag = arr[i]
    }
  }
  return flag
}

(btw. Golang is really really ulgy and hard to write!)

Ok, I had completed the task perfectly. But I learned a new way to do the same thing elegantly. Furthermore, it uses some excellent features like ruby. Now let me show you the code.

func getMax(vals ...int) int {
  flag := MINN
  for _, v range vals {
    if v > flag {
      flag = v
    }
  }
  return flag
}

... is a powerful sign and widely used in Go(and very very misleading). It can unfold slices and arrays.

After writing this post, I suddenly felt it was nothing. I can write this function more beautiful by using another languages.

Starting with C++ does really restrict my mind.Every time I use languages such as ruby, I felt like dancing with tight feet. Itâ€™s bad.

Thatâ€™s all, thank you. I felt worse.
entry.summary: In previous assignment, I was asked to implement a function which can pick the biggest number in a slice. By learning on Coursera, I found a better way to do this.

entry.content:

lv1 -A Simple Calculator

input:

1

+

2

3

è¾“å…¥åˆ†ä¸‰è¡Œé™ä½äº†å¤„ç†è¾“å…¥æ•°æ®çš„éš¾åº¦ï¼ˆå…¶å®å¹¶æ²¡æœ‰ï¼‰

package main

import "fmt"

func cal(a int, cal string, b int) int {
  switch cal {
  case "+":
    return a + b
  case "-":
    return a - b
  case "*":
    return a * b
  case "/":
    return a / b
  default:
    return 0
  }
}

func main() {
  var a, b int
  var sig string

  // fmt.Scanln(&a, &sig, &b)

  fmt.Scanln(&a)
  fmt.Scanln(&sig)
  fmt.Scanln(&b)

  fmt.Println(cal(a, sig, b))
}

æ„Ÿè§‰å†™çš„å¥½ä¸‘â€¦â€¦ä¸€ç‚¹ä¹Ÿä¸ä¼˜é›…

lv2 -Password Verifier

å’±ä¹Ÿä¸ä¼šå¼‚å¸¸å•¥çš„ï¼Œï¼Œå¾€ç®€å•é‡Œå†™ï¼Œï¼Œæ°´äº†æ°´

package main

import "fmt"

func main() {
  user := make(map[string]string)

  user["root"], user["vonhyou"] = "toor", "plmokn"

  fmt.Print("login:")
  var username, pwd string
  fmt.Scanln(&username)

  pwd, ok := user[username]
  if ok {
    fmt.Print("password:")
    fmt.Scanln(&pwd)
    if pwd == user[username] {
      fmt.Println("Welcome", username)
    } else {
      fmt.Println("Wrong password!")
    }
  } else {
    fmt.Println("User does not exist!")
  }
}

lv3 -Get The Largest Number

åº”è¯¥æ˜¯ä¸ºäº†è®©å¤§å®¶ç†Ÿæ‚‰forå¾ªç¯

å†™lv3pçš„æ—¶å€™å‘ç°maxnæœ‰ä¸ªå°bug

å°±æ˜¯flagçš„åˆå§‹å€¼ç»™çš„æ˜¯å‡æƒ³æ— ç©·å°ï¼Œï¼Œå¥½ä¹…æ²¡å†™ä»£ç å¿˜äº†å¥½å¤šä¸œè¥¿å•Š

package main

import "fmt"

func maxn(arr []int, n int) int {
  var flag int = arr[0]
  for i := 1; i < n; i++ {
    if arr[i] > flag {
      flag = arr[i]
    }
  }
  return flag
}

func main() {
  var n int
  a := make([]int, 10)
  fmt.Scanln(&n)
  for i := 0; i < n; i++ {
    fmt.Scanf("%d", &a[i])
  }
  // fmt.Println(a)
  fmt.Println(maxn(a, n))
  // fmt.Println(a[:n])
}

lv3plus -Sortï¼

æœ¬æ¥æOIé‚£ä¼šæ’åºç®—æ³•éƒ½å¿˜å¾—å·®ä¸å¤šäº†ï¼Œï¼Œç°åœ¨åˆè®©å†™

ç´¢æ€§å­¦äº†å­¦åŸºæ•°æ’åºï¼Œå®ç°äº†ä¸€ä¸‹ï¼Œï¼Œä¸çŸ¥é“æœ‰æ²¡æœ‰bug

package main

import "fmt"

func maxn(arr []int, n int) int {
  var flag int = arr[0]
  for i := 1; i < n; i++ {
    if arr[i] > flag {
      flag = arr[i]
    }
  }
  return flag
}

func insSort(a []int, exp int, n int) {
  for i := 1; i < n; i++ {
    flag := a[i]
    j := i - 1
    for j >= 0 && a[j]/exp < flag/exp {
      a[j+1] = a[j]
      j--
    }
    a[j+1] = flag
  }
}

func radixSort(a []int, n int) {
  mxn := maxn(a, n)
  mxExp := 1
  for mxn >= 10 {
    mxn /= 10
    mxExp *= 10
  }

  for i := 1; i != mxExp; i *= 10 {
    insSort(a, i, n)
  }
}

func main() {
  var n int
  a := make([]int, 10)
  fmt.Scanln(&n)
  for i := 0; i < n; i++ {
    fmt.Scanf("%d", &a[i])
  }
  radixSort(a, n)
  fmt.Println(a[:n])
}

åæ§½ï¼šgoæœ‰å¥½å¤šå¤§æ‹¬å·å•Šï¼Œï¼Œï¼Œï¼Œä¸‘æ­»äº†ï¼Œï¼Œå’‹å’Œrustä¸€ä¸ªå¾·è¡Œ
